ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of how to analyze the Constitution and make a legal argument based on history, structure and enactment of our Founding Document. I also learned general information about the US legal history and important cases.

This class provided me with the foundational tools one uses to make legal arguments. Prof. Amar did a phenomenal job of introducing us to the various legal techniques such as prudence, history, ethos, etc. 

I cannot even begin to list all the specific insights I have developed in this course this semester, but trust me, they are there.
I learned how to analyze and evaluate constitutional law, specifically with a focus on history and intent.
Close reading of the Constitution, American Constitutional history, and political theory surrounding the Constitution.

I learned more than I could ever imagine about the Constitution and ways to interpret it. Out of my entire semester, this course was definitely the one in which I learned the most concrete knowledge. I feel infinitely more confident in my ability to read the news, or any other complex constitutional issue and be equipped with the tools to properly interpret it. Professor Amar and Ben were amazing in teaching a course that incorporated history, political science and the law in a way that felt coherent and robust.

This course is largely centered around three of Prof Amar's books. However, a lot of the class is student driven -- we each post a number of discussion posts and review those in class, posing constitutional questions and relating them to current political events.
Constitutional interpretation and argumentation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish the class either followed the text more closely, was more of an open conversation format, or was a pure lecture given by Professor Amar. I also enjoyed the first half of the class which featured lecture videos to accompany the text. I wish those were available for the final book (or spread out for the duration of the class).
I wish there was a little bit more structure to the course meetings, but other than that I enjoyed it.

Strengths: Professor Amar, the assignments, the books, and the discussions
Weaknesses: Sometimes the class got veered off track and found it hard to stick to the schedule

This course was amazing in that it gave us the opportunity to discuss anything we wanted from the readings or from our own curiosity into class through the reading responses. I also loved Professor Amar's books and lectures, and studying them closely provided me with so much information and nuanced argument that I never would have known otherwise. In terms of improvements, I think it would be helpful if we maybe spent one session a week specifically focused on an aspect from the reading so I could feel more prepared for discussions, and perhaps another session every week on reading responses/personal interest questions. That would be useful just so students with less background knowledge could prepare from the readings to contribute too.

This course is not super structured, which is both a strength and a weakness. It is a strength because it means the students often drive the class in terms of what we are discussing, but a weakness in that it is difficult to be completely engaged and well-versed in every discussion topic (especially if it is getting into niche legal issues). Overall, it's a good course, and Prof Amar and the TFs are so knowledgeable about the field, so that is a major plus.
The books are well written and are good and important reads. The class discussion often gets bogged down in minutiae or obscure constitutional hypotheticals.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't know that there was anything specific to the virtual environment that changed the course. I enjoyed the ability to share the screen so that we could talk about text together.
Overall I think Prof. Amar and our TFs, Ben & Kelly, navigated this tremendously unconventional semester in stride. Very few Zoom hiccups.
The lunch hour was helpful, but I wonder if the course could have benefitted from breakout rooms or some other method of encouraging discussion.
For a Zoom seminar, this course exceeded my expectations.

The lunches before class were very useful in getting to known Professor Amar and the other students in a more informal, unrecorded manner. Otherwise, I think prerecorded lectures plus two seminars a week were great to stay engaged with the class.
The course was taught very similarly to the way I assume it would be taught in person. Not a lot of the class was geared towards COVID virtual learning, it was just treated like a standard seminar.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend the lecture course to most students, but I do believe I received more individual feedback than I would have in the lecture course.

Undoubtedly. If you feel that you dont know as much as you would like to know about the American Constitution and are interested in being taught by one of the most beautiful legal minds of our era - then yes.
Yes, especially if they are interested in law school at all.
Yes, definitely.

If another student wanted to take a course to learn about the constitution, I would honestly recommend the lecture version of this course.  As a seminar, the class is pretty unstructured and led by student discussions, which ultimately end up being rants by the professor.  Akhil Amar definitely knows what he is talking about, but his comments oftentimes leave little open for discussion for the students, and he is occasionally quite dismissive of student contributions along with being one of the most egotistical professors I've had.  Nonetheless, the class is pretty enjoyable but simply not the best way of learning the basics of constitutional law in my opinion.  Also, for any prospective students, please note that professor Amar goes over time nearly every class.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in American history, law, and even social issues more generally. Professor Amar is a passionate and incredibly knowledgeable professor who cares deeply about the intellectual progress of his students. The arguments he presented and the way he focused on both subject matter as well as methods of constitutional interpretation is something I will never forget, and hope to carry on throughout my life to matters both legal and beyond.

I mean, it's really difficult to pass up an opportunity to take a class with Amar. He knows the field so well, so it was great to her his insight (and often strong opinion) about different constitutional issues that are extremely prevalent today. Especially for political science or other adjacent majors, I would recommend this course.

I would not prioritize this course if someone is choosing between this and another class. I took it as a second semester senior and it was interesting, but it was far from the most engaging or riveting course I've taken.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None else.
N/A
Virtual lunches before class
This course was a virtual seminar, and the discussion board in canvas was used to facilitate seminar discussions.
Mix between lecture and discussion.
